comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Ha! I am not sure it is a panorama, but have often wondered what that strange old tower was. I think it was in Valentine Lane (now street) opposite Christ Church St Lawrence. It shows up in this 1844 illustration - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=411367, and I think in a John Rae drawing. Does anyone know?

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
I'm not saying it is, but it might be a shot tower.

In a shot tower, molten lead was carried or hauled to the top then poured out into the void of space. As it fell to the ground it formed droplets which were gathered and used for shot. As in shot to be fired from a shotgun.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: A better description of the shot making process is here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shot_tower

comment.author: 33546386@N03
comment._content: great shot

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
E U R E K A ! The Tower was the Tower Inn or Hancock's Tower From the Illustrated Sydney News 11/7/1889, page 10 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/63621793 -
" RIGHT facing the Benevolent Asylum looking across the broad thoroughfare where Pitt and George streets run into one another, stands the Tower Inn. At one time it was a prominent structure, and with its balconied front, and central archway leading into a regular English-looking coach-yard, it formed quite a feature in the landscape. It is now almost elbowed out of existence by the business places on each side. Eating houses, where a cheap meal is provided, oyster saloons and places where prawns and lobsters are vended, fruiterer's shops, and other similar places abound. Lifting itself above the roof line of the lower of these buildings still stands the tower - from which the old hostelry in front takes its name giving quite a feudal aspect to the scene. It has occupied that site for almost fifty years [built c.1840], and is quite an old Sydney landmark. It is built of squared stones with battlemented walls, and from the lofty embrasures some wooden cannon, or ' Quakers,' are projected. At each corner of the battlements looks out the half-length carved effigy of a king or knight, with sword in hand or battle-axe on shoulder, while a large weathercock and vane surmounting the low Norman roof indicates 'how the wind blows'. It was built by a man named Hancock, and was familiarly called 'Hancock's Tower'. Years ago many romantic legends used to cluster about this building, like the swallows that circled around it. Of these stories ever 'on the wing' was one to the effect that the builder put it up as a prison for his wife, and many a time in our child-life while passing by the place we used to fancy we could see the unfortunate lady peeping through the upper windows. But the fact is that Hancock was a shrewd, hard-working wheelwright, who had his 'smithy ' at the intersection of George-street and Market-street, just about where the palatial hotel of Charles J. Roberts now stands. Having made considerable money at his trade, Hancock settled himself down on the then somewhat rural site now under discussion, and with the national prejudice that 'an Englishman's house is his castle'. he gave his residence as warlike an aspect as possible. In the courtyard between the Tower and the Inn in front, he had a large stone statue erected, and various flower-beds and trellised arbours formed, so that altogether it was a pleasant glimpse of the Tower Inn yard some years ago. But the utilitarian spirit has waved its wand over the spot, and it now wears somewhat the look of 'Tom all-alone's'. "

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] You were right! This 1877 article (about a court case over Robert Hancock's will) suggests the tower was "built for the manufacture of shot" - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/101459346

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Hancock's Tower seems to have been built in the early 1840s and demolished late 1892, well after this photo was taken. It fell into worse disrepair than here - handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/188005 . I think this photo is between 1882 (the Farmer's building, see note) and 1885 (lack of GPO tower, unless it is hiding behind something!). So far ... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20958381@N08] & [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] and anyone else might know more ...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
This month's gold star goes to ...[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Utterly Fantastic!!! How did you discover this?
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] good speculator re the shot tower!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Discovered by looking into the interesting history of Ultimo House (1804) - I thought the Tower might have been a folly or stables (like the NSW Conservatorium) at the bottom of the parkland. Came across the ISN article (part of a series about the history of Parramatta Road), and once you have the name it is easy to find endless information via Trove, as you well know. I am still not sure EXACTLY where the Tower Inn was - some references say at the corner of George and Quay Streets, which did not used to meet according to old maps - maybe why it was demolished was to make way for the street. It seems to have been swamped by taller hotels and buildings opposite the old Sydney Railway Station - hence the great height of the photographer who took this image. Now where are those detailed maps which [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] is so good at linking to ... ... ?!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Here's a few interesting maps, but they're not much help with this one...I'll park the links here for possible future use: Illustrated Sydney News (1866) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63512745 Illustrated Sydney News (1874) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63105613 Illustrated Sydney News (1876) trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/5452604 Illustrated Sydney News (1888) bird's view nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5788833

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here are a few more images and items...of varying quality/interest nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71210912 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16906776 (plus see accompanying item 'Central') nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113330307 this 1894 Evening News item might help with the location (see item 4th from bottom, column 2)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Found it! On this 1887 very detailed map, just above the 2nd 'G' in GeorGe Street, marked as 'Tower Inn Reynold 817' - www.photosau.com.au/CoSMaps/scripts/display.asp?Term=RW%2... or hi-res .pdf - www.photosau.com.au/CoSMaps/maps/pdf/RW/sheet49.pdf The photographer must have been on top of the Station Hotel.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The Station Hotel and the Grand Hotel which was built where the Tower Inn was - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4174797251/]

And if the photographer had turned around from his perch on top of the Station Hotel, this was the view of Sydney Railway Station (not "Central" as titled) -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/2654873676/]

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] ...now you've located Hancock's Tower...given the other landmarks you've identified (eg. St George's Church in Castlereagh St), I wonder whether that mystery dome we see in this pic might be part of Hardy Brothers' Furniture Warehouse, which per the 1876 Illustrated Sydney News map, was located at the corner of Liverpool and Oxford Sts...the 1876 ISN map has a small sketch which depicts Hardy Brothers' Furniture Warehouse as a similar pavilion like structure, but sans dome trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/5452604 I'm not anywhere near 100% convinced...but if you draw a line from roughly where Hancock's Tower was located, across Hay Street between Parker Lane and Parker Street (ie. where Hordern's was then located), the Liverpool/Oxford St corner more or less lines up...if my theory is correct we should also be able to see the Museum and the Grammar School (both in College St) in the background. One issue is that Hardy Brothers appear to have become insolvent in 1880...so if this is their furniture warehouse, then they mightn't have been the occupants at the time this pic was taken...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Hmmm, Hardy Bros looks like a barrel roof to me, rather than a square dome. I really do not know, but anticipate the answer will turn up when least expected. I am also wondering what is that large warehouse to the right of St Phillips? Could it be the 1890 Wynyard Building? Meaning that the GPO tower is hidden somewhere ... All very confusing, and to make it worse a not-very-accurate but fascinating birds-eye view of Sydney in 1888 (SLNSW) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a128462.html

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] OK. I've changed maps and rulers (!). Hardy Brothers are now off my list. But...that building to the immediate left of the mystery dome looks like the Protestant Hall (completed 1877), which was at the corner of Castlereagh & Bathurst Sts nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70586930. Using my new map and ruler, it lines up more or less perfectly.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Good find with the Protestant Hall - it has lost its turretty bits, but the Castlereagh St facade is still there in [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]'s photo.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's a better candidate for the mystery dome...still using my new map and ruler...Cameron's Tobacco Factory, was at the corner of Pitt & Liverpool Sts...looks to have been 4 stories plus...burned down on 23/9/1886 (pic of the fire) nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5788421 ; (item re) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63620329 Ha! this SMH report is even better...it includes a description of the building, which refers to the cupola...per the SMH the factory had an 80ft frontage to Pitt St...110ft to Liverpool St...was 4 stories high..."...with an additional story formed by an iron covered dome or cupola..." ; we'd need to find a pic to be 100% sure...but I suspect this is the mystery dome - news.google.com/newspapers?id=8KxhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4JUDA... ; this issue of the Sydney Mail has a better illustration of the fire...amid the conflagration it even shows a dome and chimney which match up with what we see above (see illustration p. 703) news.google.com/newspapers?id=sMJPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U5MDA... If my latest theory is correct...all up I'd say the fire might explain why we can't see this building in the various early 1890s pics of Sydney...eg. www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/9021345997/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] THAT's IT! Brilliant - well done! Cameron's Tobacco Factory - I never heard mention of it before. Must have been built after 1873 as it is not in the Town Hall pano. The building was on the SE corner of Pitt and Liverpool Streets, with the main frontage on Liverpool - see 1880 very detailed map - .pdf - www.photosau.com.au/CoSMaps/maps/pdf/DP/Block_33_34_35_36... . The Shark Hotel in the old art deco Coles building is there now, according to GoogleMaps. So it puts this photo at before 1886 (the Cameron's fire AND the unbuilt GPO tower). Still puzzled by the building to the right of St Phillips - unless it is the new GPO ? The angles are so oddly unusual in this view!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Those maps are really good...It would be a real challenge to discover what that building to the rhs of St Phillip's was...it's not distinctive enough from this angle (!)...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] The great maps from a City of Sydney website have been terrific finds in the course of research on this particular photo - well worth a bookmark and browse - www.photosau.com.au/CoSMaps/scripts/home.asp

comment._content: I am finding it hard to see how St Phillips could be so far to the left.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33546386@N03] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/35672655@N00] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alisonguesdon] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sidpickle] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/94358704@N03] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63385174@N06]  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/92943860@N00] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/spelio] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelwrangler] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/miniop] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/davidbromage] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/97539983@N07] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/jennysoldcars] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mambo1935] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/la_buff] 

Unless another candidate appears in the next month, I'm giving [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] 's Hancock's Tower discovery my vote for a gold star in the 2013 Flickr sleuth awards...some 5 months on, I still think it is an amazing discovery...the subject was so intriguing it cried out loud to be discovered...and 'you-know-who' delivered! I'm still undecided re my vote for the minor placings...but for me, this one wins by a few lengths...even if the awards were backdated to include previous years, when the remarkable discoveries were coming thick and fast, I still think this one would be right up there!

Anyone else got their 'fave' discoveries? ...apologies if I've missed anyone!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [totes embarrassment!] I vote for Hera !

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] I was about to say HMS OPAL would be a contender, but I see that it was over a year ago when you proved [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]'s dogged deduction.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Always good to revisit these photos. The Anthony Hordern Palace Emporium in the Haymarket (see note) opened in October 1881, which gives us an earliest date. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/115455042 Between 1881 (Horderns) and 1886 (Camerons), so far ... Still puzzling over that tall building to the right of St Phillips ... Ed - I forgot Farmers warehouse 1882 (see note) ... 1882-86

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]  I wish I could add a note ... this blessed beta of Flickr's won't let me!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Flickr has released a beta version?

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Yes it's replaced what I will call the 'photo viewing page' and some of us lucky ones have been blessed with it. No longer can you view (or make) notes, or edit your comments (so I use Word and paste them in), nor do imported pix in square brackets appear. The Flickr help forum has gone berserk as has the facility they've introduced where people make comments is in meltdown. Hopeless. I've mow started a stream on Ipernity (and found old friends and contacts - not followers there). Not happy at this end Ben!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I can also see the archivists at places like State Records going spare ... they used Flickr as a research tool. And a very good one. Now with this 'version' or 'beta' its interface with the public is little more than Twitter with Pictures or Facebook with fotos. To get to all the supporting pages is a nighmare and wastes huge amounts of time. To think that Trove moved to the old Flickr which was a sign that the site was worthwhile - I wonder what they think now? Ipernity is looking awfully attractive right now!

comment.author: 55198937@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper]  At the left hand side of the (old) Flickr page is the apparently innocuous offer to " Try our new photo experience beta"  ..  Don't touch it - it's like pulling the pin on a hand grenade!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] On my version - there was that message plus a box allowing me to opt out. I clicked 'Opt out" but Flickr decided "nah, you're staying in" - and here I am. The opt out box has now disappeared!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Apparently the opt out option should still be there for you in the "Help & Feedback" link. Note: "If you don't see the button, try turning off any ad-block software you are running. Or scripts such as those that block the Yahoo! toolbar." EDIT: or maybe not, they may have removed the opt out function very recently.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Here we go, looks like you may be in the second "evaluation" group: "Majority of english users can opt-in and opt-out of the beta photo page experience and see 3 buttons on the help popup. Some users are locked into evaluation groups where they cannot opt-out of the new experience and see only 2 options. And a final group of english users are locked into the old experience and cannot opt-in to the new experience yet and do not see the try out the new experience button." - www.flickr.com/help/forum/en-us/72157636735976325/#reply7...

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Many thanks for the research, that's another coffee I owe you! Unfortunately I am one of the following "Some users are locked into evaluation groups where they cannot opt-out of the new experience and see only 2 options". Which is really helpful. I guess there is nothing more to do except await Flickr's pleasure.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] I might add that I really have better things to do than fiddle with Flickr!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Gentlemen,I am replying from my ASUS laptop running the same OS (Windows 7) as my desktop and guess what? No beta version in sight! Same log-in, same password different rendering on the photo-page. But the greatest joy is to see, once again, the "notes" facility and the ability to edit comments! comment.author: 21647809@N04

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I am happy to report that sometime this morning the 'new photo experience' magically disappeared from both Corinneski's and my desktops. comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: The Australian Mutual Fire Insurance Society Building (located on the SE cnr of Pitt & King Sts) was completed in 1883. Although only 3 or so stories high, it had a very distinctive tower which was later removed during renovations (ca. 1919)...I wonder whether the AMFI Building tower would/should be visible in this pic if it were there...a touch more resolution would help...but I can't see it... Here's how the AMFI looked in the 1890s, by which time there were a number of other taller buildings in Pitt St [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2533268514/] The AMFI is of course still there (sans tower)...if you want to download this PDF, this fascinating conservation management plan gives some background... www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0003/1...
